column4: Hey guys, is there a way to recognize 4gb of ram in ubuntu without using the 64bit version?
Yes, use the PAE kernel
thanks ill look into it :)
I believe the PAE kernel can address up to 48 GB of RAM
Another thing you could do is use the 64-bit kernel on your 32-bit Ubuntu system
okay.. any idea whats the best most stable method?
Use the X86-64 version of Ubuntu is the best thing to do
PAE is kind of hacky and may aggravate some 3rd party driver
I would do that but ive just heard there are a lot of application compatibilty issues with the 64bit, and im not really ready to go that route yet
it's also a bit slower than the native addressing in the 64-bit kernel
There are no issues on the X86-64 version
there's 32-bit libraries that can be used for 32-bit compatibility
they're all brought in as dependences if you isntall Wine :)
Okay, well then maybe ill dive into it, im about to reconfigure my system anyway in the next week or so cuz i got a new SSD to play with
The only reason to stay with 32-bit x86 version of Ubuntu is if your CPU does not support X86-64
then im a dummy cuz mine i deffinately a 64 bit :X

If you asked me in 2005/2006, I would have been insistent on staying with 32-bit x86 because the 32-bit compatibility libraries weren't really all there yet, but there's no good reason to not use X86-64 now
well ill deffinately give it a shot and see if it works out better for me, if it doesnt ill just roll back to 32bit
people liked to FUD X86-64 for a long time because of those early compatibility issues
that might be what i got traped in
Just bring in Wine and you'll have all the 32-bit compatibility environment you need because Wine depends on all of them
shall do :)
